intro: Anthriscus cerefolium var. longirostris, commonly known as cow parsley or bishop's crown, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and clusters of small, white or pale yellow flowers that bloom in early summer. The plant typically grows in moist, shady woodland areas and thrives in well-drained soil. It is an herbaceous perennial that can reach heights of up to 1 meter. Its flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, making it a valuable addition to wildlife-friendly gardens.
